QUESTION OF PRIVILEGE.

Mr. R. S. LAKE (Qu’Appelle). Mr. Speak- er, before-the Orders of the Day are called, . I rise to a question of privilege to call at- tention to a Imisrepresentation of my re- marks of last Thursday evening, which ap- peared in the ‘Globe’ newspaper on the 31st of March. I spoke at such a late hour that I can readily understand that some mistakes might have crept in, and I am quite sure the representatives of that paper will be very glad to make the correction. In the ‘Globe’ report I am credited with having said that I approved of the teaching of religious doctrine in the schools, al— though I regretted the opportunity was not always availed of. My actual remarks were ‘that doctrine and dogma should be kept to the church and to the home.’ The report went on to say : Although many Catholics sent their children

to the public schools, many desired to have separate schools.

I did not express any such opinion in the remarks -I made. .
